subject: Set severity for PELs
commitMessage:
Set severity for PELs

This commit adds an option to pass severity while logging PEL.
This will help to classify PELs based on their severity.
By default severity of all the PELs logged for system VPD failure
is set to be unrecoverable where as other failures are flagged as
predictive errors.

Signed-off-by: Sunny Srivastava <sunnsr25@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I9cd10a29252a42f5031b91b9c7ad2e284ed5b861

Change has been successfully merged by Santosh Puranik
Can you reword it or explain it..am not getting exactly what you are trying to tell..
spellcheck
I see this method is getting used in all of the derived class.. Why not moving it to the base class itself? so that we avoid copy of this api in all derived classes

I am not sure we need all these?
I can understand need of these 4 here- 
Debug
INformational(interprets NOTICE), 
Warning(interprets ALERT), 
Error(interprets CRITICAL/EMERGENCY)

If you are pointing to the current implementation of phosphor-logging then instead of coupling this code with respect to phosphor-logging implementation, it is better to code to the interface file which states all these as different types of severity and let phosphor-logging decide how they want to log it now or in future.

using Severity = openpower::vpd::constants::severity::PelSeverity;
you can use Severity at all places.
I know but I prefer this for some readability about what WARNING, ERROR etc means.

are you sure this should be warning?
If hardware update gets failed then there could be data mismatch.

Yes, as we discussed apart from system vpd we will log everything else as warning.
Warning is also a type of error which is kind of predictive.

If data mismatched, don't we need any action to correct this.
If we are fixing it then we can go ahead with WARNING MSG.

We need that is why we are logging the PEL, but since in this case we are continuing with the cache copy, we are just logging warning, error will mean that system is unusable which is not true in this case.

I know severity should be based on type of error but basically for all exception we are making it as ERROR if it is systemVpd otherwise WARNING.
Can we do it at first place(common to all exceptions)
Done
please follow indentation . make it aligned .
Done
now we have multiple jsons, so can we make this statement more clear that which json it will return.
please follow indentation . make it aligned .
Done

We can't state that here. the path of Json is being passed as a part of exception construction. So this method cannot know the path of JSON it will just return the path whichever is passed by the exception.
Please move this out of the header file. With this, any source file including this will get its own copy.
Done
Is there a reason why you removed the explicit modifier from the constructor?
Constructor with two parameters need not be defined as explicit.

Neither do those with a single argument. It is mostly good to prevent accidental and unintended conversions. That said, I am not too hung up on any one approach, but I would prefer taht in the future that we don't roll in changes that are not really related to the thing this commit is handling.
Naming conventions: path**
Done
Why is this needed now? Please move this to the place where the map is defined.
Ack
why don't we have these severity interfaces define in const.hpp?

Why do we need them in const.hpp? I think we are abusing const.hpp slightly. As long as this is the only place where these strings are referenced, I would be OK to leave them here. It is afr more readable.
I agree and the enum which will point to these values is already defined in const.hpp. This is just a mapping of those enums to their values.
yeah makes sense.

Can we have the parameters described with its name.
additionalData - <description>
sev - <description> etc..
Ack
decription with variable name
